title: UK bank shuts all savings accounts - carrying £99million worth of deposits
text:

UK bank Raphaels has announced plans to close all of its savings accounts as part of a major restructuring of its services.

Customers are being given 60 days to find new homes for their £99million of deposits - before their accounts seize to exist.

The lender's savings arm was known for its high interest rates on bonds and notice accounts, which, until recently, often featured in “best buy” tables.

But the bank has now written to customers to say that it is shutting these deals down for good.

"Raphaels Bank, as part of the continued reduction of its banking activities, has announced to its customers that it is closing its retail savings division," a statement said.

(Image: Getty)

"All savings account holders have been given sixty days’ notice, in line with regulatory guidelines, of the bank’s intention to return their monies to them and close their accounts."

Customers on deals with interest due in the future will be paid this in advance.

Lenlyn Group, the owners of Raphaels, has been trying to find a buyer for the bank since 2015.

In May, the Financial Conduct Authority fined the lender £1.89million for not properly supervising companies it outsourced business to.

This had resulted in thousands of its customers being unable to use their payment cards on Christmas Eve in 2015.

Last April, Raphaels stopped its car loan operation and, in 2016, Lenlyn sold Raphaels’ ATM arm to a sister company, International Currency Exchange.

The bank said its customer support team, based in Aylesbury, will be available to answer any queries customers might now have about their accounts being closed.

description: 232-year-old Raphaels Bank is axing its savings arm - meaning thousands of customers are about to see their accounts shut down
